#Text=CHAPTER XIII MOLOCH
#Text=The Barbarians had no need of a circumvallation on the side of Africa , for it was theirs .
#Text=But to facilitate the approach to the walls , the entrenchments bordering the ditch were thrown down .
#Text=Matho next divided the army into great semicircles so as to encompass Carthage the better .

#Text=The hoplites of the Mercenaries were placed in the first rank , and behind them the slingers and horsemen ; quite at the back were the baggage , chariots , and horses ; and the engines bristled in front of this throng at a distance of three hundred paces from the towers .

#Text=Amid the infinite variety of their nomenclature ( which changed several times in the course of the centuries ) these machines might be reduced to two systems : some acted like slings , and the rest like bows .
#Text=The first , which were the catapults , was composed of a square frame with two vertical uprights and a horizontal bar .

#Text=In its anterior portion was a cylinder , furnished with cables , which held back a great beam bearing a spoon for the reception of projectiles ; its base was caught in a skein of twisted thread , and when the ropes were let go it sprang up and struck against the bar , which , checking it with a shock , multiplied its power .
#Text=The second presented a more complicated mechanism .

#Text=A cross-bar had its centre fixed on a little pillar , and from this point of junction there branched off at right angles a short of channel ; two caps containing twists of horse-hair stood at the extremities of the cross-bar ; two small beams were fastened to them to hold the extremities of a rope which was brought to the bottom of the channel upon a tablet of bronze .
#Text=This metal plate was released by a spring , and sliding in grooves impelled the arrows .

#Text=The catapults were likewise called onagers , after the wild asses which fling up stones with their feet , and the ballistas scorpions , on account of a hook which stood upon the tablet , and being lowered by a blow of the fist , released the spring .

#Text=Their construction required learned calculations ; the wood selected had to be of the hardest substance , and their gearing all of brass ; they were stretched with levers , tackle-blocks , capstans or tympanums ; the direction of the shooting was changed by means of strong pivots ; they were moved forward on cylinders , and the most considerable of them , which were brought piece by piece , were set up in front of the enemy .

#Text=Spendius arranged three great catapults opposite the three principle angles ; he placed a ram before every gate , a ballista before every tower , while carroballistas were to move about in the rear .
#Text=But it was necessary to protect them against the fire thrown by the besieged , and first of all to fill up the trench which separated them from the walls .

#Text=They pushed forward galleries formed of hurdles of green reeds , and oaken semicircles like enormous shields gliding on three wheels ; the workers were sheltered in little huts covered with raw hides and stuffed with wrack ; the catapults and ballistas were protected by rope curtains which had been steeped in vinegar to render them incombustible .
#Text=The women and children went to procure stones on the strand , and gathered earth with their hands and brought it to the soldiers .
#Text=The Carthaginians also made preparations .
#Text=Hamilcar had speedily reassured them by declaring that there was enough water left in the cisterns for one hundred and twenty-three days .
#Text=This assertion , together with his presence , and above all that of the zaïmph among them , gave them good hopes .
#Text=Carthage recovered from its dejection ; those who were not of Chanaanitish origin were carried away by the passion of the rest .
#Text=The slaves were armed , the arsenals were emptied , and every citizen had his own post and his own employment .
#Text=Twelve hundred of the fugitives had survived , and the Suffet made them all captains ; and carpenters , armourers , blacksmiths , and goldsmiths were intrusted with the engines .
#Text=The Carthaginians had kept a few in spite of the conditions of the peace with Rome .
#Text=These were repaired .
#Text=They understood such work .
#Text=The two northern and eastern sides , being protected by the sea and the gulf , remained inaccessible .
#Text=On the wall fronting the Barbarians they collected tree-trunks , mill-stones , vases filled with sulphur , and vats filled with oil , and built furnaces .
#Text=Stones were heaped up on the platforms of the towers , and the houses bordering immediately on the rampart were crammed with sand in order to strengthen it and increase its thickness .
#Text=The Barbarians grew angry at the sight of these preparations .
#Text=They wished to fight at once .
#Text=The weights which they put into the catapults were so extravagantly heavy that the beams broke , and the attack was delayed .
#Text=At last on the thirteenth day of the month of Schabar , — at sunrise , — a great blow was heard at the gate of Khamon .

#Text=Seventy-five soldiers were pulling at ropes arranged at the base of a gigantic beam which was suspended horizontally by chains hanging from a framework , and which terminated in a ram ’s head of pure brass .

#Text=It had been swathed in ox-hides ; it was bound at intervals with iron bracelets ; it was thrice as thick as a man ’s body , one hundred and twenty cubits long , and under the crowd of naked arms pushing it forward and drawing it back , it moved to and fro with a regular oscillation .
